definition: conducting business impartially (idiom); to act justly

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
to do/to manage/to handle/to go about/to run/to set up/to deal with
texture/grain (of wood)/inner essence/intrinsic order/reason/logic/truth/science/natural science (esp. physics)/to manage/to pay attention to/to run (affairs)/to handle/to put in order/to tidy up
to bend the law in order to favor one's relatives or associates (idiom)
to know the law and break it (idiom); consciously going against the rules
to forgive easily/to let off lightly (often with negative: you won't get away with it)
to carry out official duties and observe the law
to shield (a miscreant) from punishment, criticism etc/to take sb's side
to bring to justice/to punish according to the law
